column1: Phonological disorder is a type of speech disorder known as an articulation disorder.
This disorder is more common in boys.
Only family members may be able to understand a child who has a more severe phonological speech disorder.
Commonly, children with this disorder have: - Problems with words that begin with two consonants.
The child may either leave out these sounds, not pronounce them clearly, or use a different sound in their place.
Speech therapy may be helpful for more severe symptoms or speech problems that do not get better.
Therapy may help the child create the sound, for example by showing where to place the tongue or how to form the lips when making a sound.
Many children eventually develop almost normal speech.
In milder forms, the child may have difficulty being understood by people outside the immediate family.
